Authors:
Svante Martinsson, Klas Malmberg, Torkild Bakken, Tatiana
Korshunova, Alexander Martynov, Kennet Lundin
Title:
Integration of morphological, ecological and molecular data
reveal two new species of Doto (Nudibranchia: Dotidae) from the
Northeast Atlantic, with a discussion on food specialization
Journal:
Journal of Zoological Systematics and Evolutionary
Research
Keywords:
Multispecies Coalescent, BPP, Sweden, Northern Ireland,
Norway
Abstract:
The nudibranch genus Doto is taxonomically problematic and
contains unresolved species complexes with minor differences in
morphology. Here we study the morphology, including radular
ultrastructure, of NE Atlantic species, with focus on D. fragilis s.l.
We also tested the species boundaries with multi-locus species
delimitation analysis, estimated phylogenies, as well as reviewed the
food specificity of Doto species. Based on the results we describe two
new Doto species from the NE Atlantic; D. malinka and D. tinekvammeae,
both formerly included in D. fragilis s.l. For the molecular analysis
two markers were used, the mitochondrial COI, and the nuclear H3. Of
those included in the study, eleven species of Doto were shown to be
distinctly delimited. The Doto fragilis species complex includes at
least five species, the nominate D. fragilis and two new species D.
malinka and D. tinekvammeae, as well as D. hystrix and D. formosa, but
with no observed genetic separation between D. hystrix and D. fragilis
s.l. We also found that specimens from Sweden seemingly close to D.
maculata in external morphology having identical sequences as D.
coronata. Analysis of food preferences of the species involved in the
study contradicts the notion of strict monophagy within Doto.
